pullRequest.body:
If `f` is a function restricted to a set `t` and `s ⊆ t`, define its restriction to `s`. Add similar definitions with finsets and restrictions to Iic intervals. Prove measurability and continuity.

---

If you are moving or deleting declarations, please include these lines at the bottom of the commit message

Deletions:

Any other comments you want to keep out of the PR commit should go

This PR/issue depends on:
* ~~leanprover-community/mathlib4#16300~~
By **[Dependent Issues](https://github.com/z0al/dependent-issues)** (🤖). Happy coding!
<!-- By Dependent Issues (Action) - DO NOT REMOVE -->

I'm not sure about the name "projection". For me, a projection would rather be a postcomposition with something. Here, you're precomposing with something, so it's more a restriction -- in fact, both in the PR description and in the file-level docstring you use the word restriction. What about switching from `proj` to `restr`? This looks also more discoverable to me, as restriction is less overloaded than projection.

In fact in my mind I see it as a projection because I interpret the function as an element of a product space, but it is true that it is also a restriction. In fact [Set.restrict](https://leanprover-community.github.io/mathlib4_docs/Mathlib/Data/Set/Function.html#Set.restrict) is exactly `proj`. So I think I'll build on that.

bors r+
Thanks!

Pull request successfully merged into master.

Build succeeded:
  * [Build](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/actions/runs/10880934746/job/30188817283)
  * [Lint style](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/actions/runs/10880934746/job/30188817636)

```suggestion
* `Function.projNat n f`: Restricts the function `f` to the variables indexed by integers
```
`smaller` is ambiguous. Do you mean `< n` or `≤ n`?
Do you really need this one, and all the other finset guys, or is it enough to work with sets and the coercion from finsets to sets?

I think I do. Let me explain why.

The main issue I have is with `proj₂`. If I have `s t : Finset i` and `hst : s \subset t`, then `proj₂ hst` does weird things. The problem is typically that `hst` is interpreted as an inclusion of multisets (which is the definition), and this causes trouble when doing some rewrite with `proj₂_comp_proj` for instance. So I would have to write `Finset.coe_subset.2 hst` each time, which does not seem ideal.

So I thought I would have to add `fproj₂`. Now consider the following mwe:
```lean
import Mathlib

open MeasureTheory

variable {ι : Type*} {α : ι → Type*} [∀ i, MeasurableSpace (α i)]

def proj (s : Set ι) (x : (i : ι) → α i) (i : s) : α i := x i

def fproj₂ {s t : Finset ι} (hst : s ⊆ t) (x : (i : t) → α i) (i : s) : α i := x ⟨i.1, hst i.2⟩

theorem fproj₂_comp_proj {s t : Finset ι} (hst : s ⊆ t) :
    (fproj₂ hst) ∘ (@proj ι α t) = proj s.toSet := rfl

theorem measurable_proj (s : Set ι) : Measurable (@proj ι α s) :=
  measurable_pi_lambda _ fun _ ↦ measurable_pi_apply _

theorem measurable_fproj₂ {s t : Finset ι} (hst : s ⊆ t) :
    Measurable (fproj₂ (α := α) hst) :=
  measurable_pi_lambda _ fun _ ↦ measurable_pi_apply _

example (s t : Finset ι) (hst : s ⊆ t) (μ : Measure (Π i, α i)) : μ.map (@proj ι α s) = sorry := by
  rewrite [← fproj₂_comp_proj hst, ← Measure.map_map (measurable_fproj₂ _) (measurable_proj _)]
  sorry
```

Here `rewrite` does not recognize `proj` when I write `measurable_proj _`. I know this tactic can't see through definitions, but in that case I find it very annoying having to specify the set. I don't really understand what happens here but it's annoying. So I thought I would also add `fproj`.
In my project I'm only dealing with finsets, and though `↑↑s : Type` is defeq to `↑s : Type`, the former seems to create some difficulties, typically asking for a `rfl` after a `rewrite`, which does not happen with the latter.

For all those reasons, I think this version better. I agree it is a bit unsatisfying to have that kind of duplicate, but on the other hand it feels much more comfortable. Maybe I'm doing something wrong, it's a bit difficult to convey the difficulties I met because those are on tiny examples from previous tests I deleted, but please don't hesitate if you have some suggestions!

Since the basic notation is very general, I would put it in a file with low imports, to make sure it can be used early on. And I would move the parts that need measurability to another file, probably in the `MeasureTheory` folder. And the parts about continuity to another file in the `Topology` folder.

> Since the basic notation is very general, I would put it in a file with low imports

You mean I should move the measurability and continuity sections so that the imports of the def are low right?
I moved them close to similar results for `Function.update`, tell me if it's okay. Also I hope the way I included my own variables for the `Nat` case is okay.
Hmmm this creates a conflict because of an `assert_not_exists Nat.instLocallyFiniteOrder` in `EMetricSpace.Defs`. Should I move continuity results to their own file then?

Yes, if you can't find a suitable place, just create a new file. But I think you should also split the original file, into the very general part that doesn't depend on Nat, and the Nat-specific one which has much stronger imports.

I generalized the `Nat` version to preorders. I put the definition in `Mathlib.Order.Restriction`, and created `Mathlib.Topology.PreorderRestrict` and `Mathlib.MeasureTheory.MeasurableSpace.PreorderRestrict`.
Could you use `π` instead of `β`, to make sure that the names are the same between the different restriction variants? This is important when you name the implicit argument.

```suggestion
# Restriction of a function indexed by a preorder
```

```suggestion
lemma frestrict₂_apply {a b : α} (hab : a ≤ b) (f : (i : Iic b) → β i) (i : Iic a) :
```

```suggestion
lemma restrict_apply (a : α) (f : (a : α) → β a) (i : Iic a) : restrict a f i = f i := rfl
```
Maybe call it `restrictLe`? People might want to restrict to other kinds of intervals.
continuous, rather?
name is weird.

```suggestion
This is defined in this file as `Preorder.restrictLe a f`.
```

I'm not sure these lemmas are enough to let `fun_prop` work well. For instance,
```lean
import Mathlib
lemma foo {α β : Type*} {f : α → β} [MeasurableSpace α] [MeasurableSpace β] (hf : Measurable f) 
    (s : Set α) : Measurable (s.restrict f) :=
  -- by fun_prop -- fails
  hf.comp measurable_subtype_coe
```
Do you think this lemma (and its friends) would be worth adding?

I didn't expect `fun_prop` to work here. I use restrictions as projections in a `Pi` space (the function `f ↦ s.restrict f`), and prove these projections are measurable. But this says nothing about the measurability of the restriction (`a ↦ s.restrict f a`). It seems nobody ever needed it, but I just remembered I used it in my first ever Lean project so I'll add them for completeness.
But I don't think it really makes sense to add those in the preorder case.

pullRequest.title: [Merged by Bors] - feat: more definitions for the restriction of a dependent function

source.title: [Merged by Bors] - feat: rewrite cylinders and projective families of measures in terms of `Finset.restrict`
